TypeSignature.Value: .class nested protected auto ansi beforefieldinit DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell/DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCellAccessibleObject extends System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewColumnHeaderCell/DataGridViewColumnHeaderCellAccessibleObject

Docs.summary: Provides information about a to accessibility client applications.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Windows Forms includes built-in accessibility support that allows your application to work with accessibility client applications. Examples of accessibility client applications include screen enlarger and reviewer utilities, voice input utilities, on-screen keyboards, alternative input devices, and keyboard enhancement utilities.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCellAccessibleObject> class inherits from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> class to provide information about a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell> to accessibility client applications. Each class that represents a visual part of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> - such as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewColumnHeaderCell>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell> - also contains a class that inherits from <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> to provide information about the containing class and perform actions on behalf of accessibility client applications.
There are instances when you will want to provide additional information, such as the name or description of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> control, to accessibility client applications. There are two ways of providing this additional information. To provide limited accessibility information for existing controls, set the control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleName%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleDescription%2A> property values, which will be reported to accessibility client applications.
> [!NOTE] > You should change the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleDefaultActionDescription%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibleRole%2A> property values only in rare situations, such as if you make a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> look like a list.
Occasionally, you might require more accessibility information or different accessibility actions to be included with your custom <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell>. To customize accessibility, you can write your own class that derives from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.DataGridViewAccessibleObject> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell.DataGridViewCellAccessibleObject> classes and override the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.CreateAccessibilityInstance%2A> method. For example, if you are writing a custom row header cell that implements unique custom actions, such as special hit testing within your cell, you should create a class that inherits from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell.DataGridViewRowHeaderCellAccessibleObject> class and override the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRowHeaderCell.CreateAccessibilityInstance%2A> method.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> exposes its data structure by using <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleRole> values to define the data table hierarchy. For more information on exposing data tables to Microsoft Active Accessibility, see "Exposing Data Tables through Microsoft Active Accessibility" in the MSDN library at http://msdn.microsoft.com/library.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCellAccessibleObject.DoDefaultAction%2A> method calls the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.SelectAll%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method.

MemberSignature.Value: Public Overrides ReadOnly Property Name As String
public: virtual property System::String ^ Name { System::String ^ get(); };

remarks.format: ## Remarks If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewCell.Value%2A> property of the owning <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell> has been set, this property returns <xref:System.String.Empty>. Otherwise, this property returns "Top Left Header Cell" if the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.RightToLeft%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> control is <xref:System.Windows.Forms.RightToLeft.No>, and "Top Right Header Cell" otherwise.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance class System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject Navigate(valuetype System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation navigationDirection) cil managed
Public Overrides Function Navigate (navigationDirection As AccessibleNavigation) As AccessibleObject

Docs.returns: An that represents an object in the specified direction.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When you specify the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.Next> value for `navigationDirection`, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCellAccessibleObject.Navigate%2A> method returns an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject> that represents the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewColumnHeaderCell> for the first column. <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCellAccessibleObject.Navigate%2A> returns the same object if you specify <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.Right> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation.Left> when right-to-left support is enabled. All other <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleNavigation> values return `null`.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig virtual instance void Select(valuetype System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection flags) cil managed
Public Overrides Sub Select (flags As AccessibleSelection)

Docs.param: A bitwise combination of the values.
Docs.summary: Modifies the selection in the control or sets input focus to the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The following table describes the action performed for each `flags` value.
|Parameter value|Action| |---------------------|------------| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection.TakeFocus>|Sets input focus to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView> control. If the control contains any visible cells, sets focus to the cell in the first row and column.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection.AddSelection>|If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridView.MultiSelect%2A> property value is `true`, selects all cells in the control.| |<xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection.RemoveSelection>|If the `flags` value does not contain the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection.AddSelection> value, clears the selection in the control.| |All other <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleSelection> values|No action is taken.|

Docs.permission: to call unmanaged code. Demand value: . Permission value:

MemberSignature.Value: Public Overrides ReadOnly Property State As AccessibleStates
public: virtual property System::Windows::Forms::AccessibleStates State { System::Windows::Forms::AccessibleStates get(); };

Docs.value: A bitwise combination of values. The default is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCellAccessibleObject.State%2A> property value always includes the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Selectable> value. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCellAccessibleObject.State%2A> value includes the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Selected> value if all visible cells in the control are selected. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCellAccessibleObject.State%2A> value includes the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleStates.Offscreen> value if the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewTopLeftHeaderCell> is hidden.
